divs: sighting detailsi know a lot of folks saw this last night. nasa is 'taking' responsibility, claiming that an experimental rocket they fired at 7:46 is the cause. the article i read on cnn is poorly written, and does not describe what i saw, nor does the explanation provided by nasa quite jibe with my knowledge of atmospherics and light behavior (more on that below.) i was in my front yard, sitting by a small wood fire, enjoying the evening. the sky was clear, with very thin, high cloud 'veins'. the clouds were so thin stars were visible through them. i was watching the sky when i noticed a bright spot appear to the east, approximately 40 degrees above the horizon. in about 8 seconds the light point grew to app. 5x the brightness of jupiter (also visible to the south). at about the ten second mark, a cone of light spread out from beneath the point light. this cone spread quickly, in about 3 seconds the cone, at its widest, was about the width of 6 full moons. it had two darker 'veins' in it, sort of like crepuscular rays, that extended down and out (and slightly to the left (or north) from the light. the point of light faded out after another 8 seconds, and then the cone slowly lost its brilliance and became fuzzy. the whole thing lasted 60 seconds or so. there was no sound and i did not notice any movement to the point light during the sighting (other reports indicate they saw a slight drift to the light.) perhaps the cnn article i referenced above is just poorly written. it mentions a "series" of lights, but i only saw one. also, according to the article, the sightings were 'from massachusetts to new jersey.' i'm in northern virginia, and some of the reports here in the mufon database are from west virginia, pennsylvania, maryland, and virginia. also, nasa seems to be indicating that this was caused by sunlight reflecting off of high altitude clouds, seeded by this rocket. that does not explain what i witness last evening; if i were to try to explain it using nasas info, i would think that the rocket ignited its stage four booster (the point light) which in turn illuminated the vapor \ exhaust particles in the atmosphere. this does not explain the cone appearing after the light was already at almost full brightness, nor does it account for the 'afterglow' of the cone once the point light went out. this event being related to sunlight on high altitude clouds seems (as is intimated in the nasa explanation) is way off: this was not sunlight on clouds. i am not saying that nasa is full of it, i am just saying the article is poorly written and the facts presented there do not fully explain what i witnessed. regardless of any explanation, it was an extremely beautiful sight and i am glad others were witness to it.
